Primary Methodology: 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories
Methodology Details: The methodology we applied is based on 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories. However, in some parts, we use the more suitable methods or coefficients for local GHG emission data calculation, if there are some from researches. For example, the methane and N2O emission in agricultural sector, there are some coefficients which are notified by Council of Agriculture, Executive Yuan, Taiwan.

Primary Methodology: Other: IPCC 1995 GWP
Methodology Details: GHG emissions counting in Taipei City contain 6 categories, which include transportation, residence & business, industry, waste, agriculture as well as forestry, and Scope 1 & 2 activities.

Primary Methodology: Other: Defra's 2009 guidance on how to measure and report your GHG emissions. It is based on the GHG Protocol, the internationally recognised standard. http://www.defra.gov.uk/publications/files/pb13309-ghg-guidance-0909011.pdf
Methodology Details:
The London Energy and Greenhouse Gas Inventory (LEGGI) 2008 is a database of geographically referenced datasets of energy consumption within the Greater London area and estimates of the quantity of resulting greenhouse gases (GHG) – carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O), hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), perfluorocarbons (PFCs) and sulphur hexafluoride (SF6) – emitted into the air. The LEGGI shows energy use and GHG emissions allocated on an “end-user” basis – the general principle here is that energy use and GHG emissions are distributed according to the point of energy consumption (or point of emission if not energy related). GHG emissions from the production of goods are assigned to where the production takes place (except electricity production). GHG emissions from the production of goods that are exported are included, and emissions from the production of goods that are imported are excluded. 

The methodology uses the guidance set out in C1.2

Gas ene electricity data is 2009 (latest national data set), transport is 2010

Melbourne's methodology and boundary for municipal GHG emissions report are based on our 2008 Zero Net Strategy document.  
http://www.melbourne.vic.gov.au/enterprisemelbourne/environment/Pages/Zeronetemissions.aspx

Primary Methodology: International Standard for Determining Greenhouse Gas Emissions for Cities (World Bank)
Methodology Details:
For Greenhouse Gas Inventory in Bogotá, we used the methodology of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change - IPCC 2006 version, was fiscal year 2008, the period for which it is considered that there was sufficient information for implementation methodology. 2006 version of the IPCC methodology, GHG emissions divided into four (4) groups of origin or modules: 1) power module, 2) module manufacturing processes and product use, 3) module of agriculture, forestry and other land uses and 4) waste module. 

GHG emissions are accounted for in each module as well: In the power module GHG emissions from fuel combustion and fugitive emissions from fuels handling, in the form of Industrial Processes and Product Use, GHG emissions caused by industrial processes (use and transformation of raw materials through chemical and physical processes) and non-energy uses of carbon in fossil fuels, in the form of agriculture, forestry and other land uses are considered emissions and removals GHGs, and the different forms of carbon stored in all land types, and basically waste module GHG emissions generated by the decomposition of organic matter in solid and liquid waste. Basically what is done is to organize information according to the requirements of the methodology and relate it to specific emission factors for each type of power sector where the quality and detail of available information is better, the level of uncertainty in the calculation decreases.

Primary Methodology: International Emissions Analysis Protocol (ICLEI)
Methodology Details:
Portland and Multnomah County gather data on carbon emissions to inform policy and programmatic decisions and to monitor overall progress toward emission goals. In general, the methodology follows guidelines developed by ICLEI — Local Governments for Sustainability and uses the Clean Air and Climate Protection software developed jointly by ICLEI and STAPPA/ALAPCO.
 
The Multnomah County inventory includes all emissions associated with electricity, natural gas, fuel oil (distillate and residual), propane, gasoline, diesel and solid waste disposal. These sources are discussed in further detail below.

Electricity is distributed to customers in Multnomah County by Portland General Electric (PGE) and Pacific Power (PP). Both PGE and PP provide data on the number of kilowatt-hours (kWh) sold to their distribution customers in each of three sectors: residential, commercial and industrial. Because these total numbers include sales of “green power” (i.e., power generated from sources that do not emit carbon emissions) to customers who have elected to purchase such power, these numbers are adjusted to determine how many kWh were sold to customers in Multnomah County from the utilities’ standard sources.
To calculate the carbon emissions from grid power, the inventory uses emission factors provided by eGRID for the Northwest Power Pool of the Western Electricity Coordinating Council.

NW Natural, the sole natural gas utility for Multnomah County, provides data on the total therms used in the county by the residential, commercial and industrial sectors. The carbon emissions attributable to natural gas usage are calculated by multiplying the total number of therms by the conversion factor provided by ICLEI for converting therms to CO2-e. 

Fuel oil data are taken from the U.S. Energy Information Administration’s “Annual Fuel Oil and Kerosene Sales Report” contained in the Petroleum Supply Annual (EIA Report), which publishes data on the sales in Oregon of heating oil, propane and kerosene. Figures are broken down in the three residential, commercial and industrial customer classes. In the absence of more specific information about usage in Multnomah County, the inventory assigns the county a share based on the percent of Oregon’s population living in Multnomah County. ICLEI provides conversion factors for carbon emissions associated with each of these heating fuels. The carbon emissions from these fuels attributable to Multnomah County are calculated by multiplying the total amount of each fuel by the applicable conversion factor.

Emissions from gasoline are calculated based on the number of gallons of gasoline sold in Multnomah County. The State of Oregon, which collects a county gas tax on behalf of Multnomah County, issues quarterly reports detailing the total gallons of gasoline sold in the county. Gasoline sales provide an imperfect measure, since clearly some people who drive in Multnomah County purchase gasoline outside of the county while others purchase it in the county but drive elsewhere. 

The EIA Report contains data for the sales in Oregon of diesel fuel and certain other transportation fuels used for rail, shipping, on-highway use, military uses and off -highway use. Because of the interstate and international character of air, rail and shipping, ICLEI recommends not attributing fuel used by these modes to a given locality, and the inventory excludes these. The inventory allocates to Multnomah County a share of Oregon’s total sales of diesel for on-highway and construction use according to population. 

Metro operates the solid waste transfer stations serving Multnomah County and provides data on the total tonnage of materials landfilled each year from the Metro region. The inventory assigns a share of the total tonnage to Multnomah County based on the percent of Metro population that is in Multnomah County. The Oregon Department of Environmental Quality (DEQ) conducts studies to determine the composition of waste in Oregon landfills. Thus, it is possible to estimate the composition of waste buried in landfills that are attributable to Multnomah County.

Some landfills capture methane gas and flare it. For each landfill that receives waste from Metro, DEQ provides an estimate of the percentage of methane captured. Using ICLEI’s Clean Air and Climate Protection software, and based on the Metro tonnage data, DEQ waste composition studies and estimates of methane recapture rates, the inventory estimates the total amount of methane generated at landfills that is released into the atmosphere. Landfill emissions included in the inventory reflect the cumulative future methane emissions that can be expected from waste disposed in a given year, as opposed to the amount of actual methane emissions from landfills in that year.

Primary Methodology: 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories
Other:
Methodology Details: The Mayor's Office of Sustainability worked closely with the Delaware Valley Regional Planning Commission to align methodologies for the 2010 Community Greenhouse Gas inventory. A detailed description of the methodology will be included in the fina report, which will be published in June 2012.

Primary Methodology: The International Basic Standard for Community-Scale GHG Emission Inventories (ICLEI/C40/WB)
Methodology Details: Emissions were estimated based on network electricity and gas data, and estimates for waste and transport emissions.   Source data was converted to emissions using Australian Greenhouse Factors.

Primary Methodology: Other: Draft Community-Scale GHG Emissions Accounting and Reporting Protocol (ICLEI)
Methodology Details: Community inventory includes draft framework provided by 2011 Draft Reporting Protocol from ICLEI.  Community inventory also references emission factors from The Climate Registry Local Governement Operations Protocol and Utility specific emission factors.

Primary Methodology: Other: Denver used a hybrid methodology that mostly employs World Resources Institute (WRI) protocols and ICLEI/C40.  WRI was used mostly for upstream (indirect) emissions that occur outside of our political boundaries (fuel, concete, food and packaging).
Methodology Details:
Our methodology is best described in a peer-reviewed journal paper "A Demand-Centered, Hybrid
Life-Cycle Methodology for City-Scale Greenhouse Gas Inventories" located at http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/es702992q

Primary Methodology: Other: Energy use
Methodology Details: We calculate the energy use. That means the use of gas, oil, coal. For the transportsector we look  at the amount of km per roadtype and per vehikeltype,. Basis for use of transportfuel and therefore basis for CO2 emissions.

Primary Methodology: Other: Action Plan of the City of Yokohama for Climate Change Measures(Measures for Local Areas)( 2011) formulated based on Article 20-3 of the Act on Promotion of Global Warming Countermeasures, we calculate the emission of GHG by the city offices and businesses. Calculated based on the Formulation Manual of Global Warming Countermeasure Action Plan for Local Government Organizations (Local Policy), First Edition.
Methodology Details:
Carbon dioxide (CO2)
Methane (CH4)
Dinitrogen monoxide (N2O)
Hydrofluorocarbon (HFC)
Perfluorocarbon (PFC)
Sulfur hexafluoride (SF6)
 *Calculation method is only for CO2
-CO2: Emission from burning fuel (electricity included) and emission from burning waste
[Emission from burning fuel]
Fuel:Calculated by multiplying CO2 emission factor to the annual usage amount of heavy oil, city gas, etc. of economy sections, energy conversion, industrial, businesses, households, and transportation, based on the statistical data of each fuel and.
Electricity: By Indirect emission method. Calculated by multiplying CO2 emission factor (disclosed by the power company) to the annual usage of electricity by each section.
[Emission from burning wastes]
CO2 emission factor is multiplied to the amount of wastes that are incinerated annually. Based on the international rule, CO2 emission from waste originating from biomass are excluded.
-CH4: Emission from burning waste, agriculture, wastes, conversion of greenery
-N2O: Emission from burning waste, industrial process, organic solvent and use of other products, agriculture, and wastes
-HFC, PFC, SF6: Emission from manufacturing, usage, and disposal stages

The statistic report is under construction and will be available at the end of the year 2012.

There is a study about the potential of renewable energy and emissions http://www.aue.bs.ch/energiestudie-bs-endbericht-2011.pdf

The report  http://www.aue.bs.ch/energiestudie-bs-endbericht-2011.pdf is according to the methodology of  http://www.stadtzuerich.ch/content/dam/stzh/dib/Deutsch/Energieversorgung/Publikationen%20und%20Broschueren/PRZH_2kW_Methodikpapier_2009-05-06.pdf

The energy and CO2-emission statistic (which will be published every two years and will be puplished the first time at the end of 2012) is under construction. It follows the rules of reporting of the climate convention.

Primary Methodology: Other: The Guidline set by Japanese Ministry of Environment
Methodology Details:
Basically we follow a guideline set by the Ministry of Environment, which is called the "Guideline for local governments about establishing local climate change action plans". However, if there are new international or domestic methods which are more applicable, we use those methods too.

-Targets of calculations are CO2, CH4, N2O, HFC, PFC and SF6.
-We calculate CO2 equivalent amount of emission for each gas by multiplying the amount of each emission by its global warming potential.
-Emissions are calculated by economic sectors: Residential, Commercial, Industrial and Transportation.
-Indirect CO2 emissions from consumption of purchased electricity are also included.
-Concerning emissions from trains, ships, and airplanes, we calculate them within the geographic boundary of TMG conforming to the international rule.

Primary Methodology: The International Basic Standard for Community-Scale GHG Emission Inventories (ICLEI/C40/WB)
Methodology Details: Information reported to CDP is consistent with New York City's greenhouse gas inventory published in September 2011. At time of CDP submission, the The International Basic Standard for Community-Scale GHG Emission Inventories (ICLEI/C40/WB) was still under development, so New York City was not able to verify full compliance with this standard. However, the City is currently piloting this approach and intends to revise its accounting and reporting methodology for upcoming inventories. As reported in its September 2001 inventory, New York City has elected to include emissions from the transport of solid waste to landfills outside of the city in its community inventory, consistent with the inclusion of this source in the local government operations inventory (this source will likely be excluded from future inventories). Consistent with the forthcoming, draft International Basic Standard for Community-Scale GHG Emissions Inventories (ICLEI/C40/WB), New York City has also has elected to include emissions associated with the decomposition of solid waste exported outside of the city as part of its community emissions total. New York City used the waste commitment method for estimating GHG emissions from landfilled and converted solid waste - this differs from the first order decay method required by the The International Basic Standard for Community-Scale GHG Emission Inventories (ICLEI/C40/WB), which New York City will use for future GHG inventories. New York City did not include emissions from marine transportation in its September 2011 GHG inventory - this will also be included in future GHG inventories. New York City also used custom emissions coefficients for electricity and steam.

Primary Methodology: The International Basic Standard for Community-Scale GHG Emission Inventories (ICLEI/C40/WB)
Methodology Details:
For the city of Rotterdam the GHG protocol is used and the governmental boundaries apply, hence including the port. The Rotterdam Climate Initiative (RCI) uses scope 1 for its target: 50% reduction of the CO2 emissions in 2025 compared to the 1990 level. 
Some 88% of the CO2 emissions is caused by the industry in the Port of Rotterdam. 
Next to that we monitor the scope 2 emissions for the built environment. This number is filled in in C1.5.  
In December 2011 an inventory was made on the emissions in 2009 of the other green house gasses, but these numbers are not yet final (and the accuracy is limited). These numbers are not included in C1.5.

Primary Methodology: 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories
Methodology Details: IPCC

Primary Methodology: Other: International Local Government GHG Emissions Analysis Protocol Version 1.0; and Local Government Operations Protocol for the Quantification and Reporting of Greenhouse Gas Emissions Inventories Version 1.1
Methodology Details: The protocols used were designed to provide standardized set of guidelines to assist local governments in quantifying and reporting GHG emissions associated with their government and community operations. Both protocols are based upon the Corporate GHG Protocol developed by the World Resources Institute (WRI) and the World Business Council for Sustainable Development (WBCSD) as well as technical guidance provided by the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC).

Primary Methodology: Other: Statistical Institute Berlin-Brandenburg,
Methodology Details:
The balance of energy-related CO2 emissions is calculated according to a methodology agreed between the German states. There are two ways to look at energy-related CO2 emissions. The calculation of carbon balance based on primary energy sources is subdivided by the sources of emissions, energy transformation and final energy consumption. This method shows only the total amount of carbon dioxide emitted in the city but it does not include the impact of external electricity trade. Therefore, the consumption of final energy consumers is not reflected. That is why Berlin prefers a method which is a consumption-based accounting of CO2 emissions. This methodology of calculating CO2 emissions is based on data from the end-use sectors, and puts electricity imports into account. It also adds to the end-users’ emissions those produced by generation of electricity and district heating in the energy transformation sector. Consumption-based accounting of CO2 emissions is therefore one indicator to find out the end-users’ emissions in a region.
The calculation is based on the energy balance as comprehensive and complete presentation of the energy consumption as a basis. In addition there are specific CO2 factors necessary based on the calorific value of an energy source offered by the Federal Environment Agency differentiated according to energy source and application.

Primary Methodology: 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories
Methodology Details:
Since an ICLEI – Local Governments for Sustainability community inventory protocol is still in
the process of being produced, the City of Houston is utilizing the 2008 Local Government
Operations Protocol (LGOP) and the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas
Inventories for the community inventory. However, it is noted that according to ICLEI, the
community inventory protocol will mirror the LGOP, which also incorporates the 2006 IPCC
Guidelines (Yienger, 2009, personal communication). Also, it must be noted that the two
existing documents that specifically address the Project 2 Degrees (P2D) software were heavily
utilized and frequently cited the 2006 IPCC Guidelines.

Primary Methodology: Other: and 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories
Methodology Details:
Several protocols for estimating GHG emissions were used to prepare the 2010 Regional GHG Inventory, as no standard protocol for the development of local or regional community-wide inventories currently exists. ICLEI is expected to release a community inventory protocol in 2012, however, and may be utilized for future updates to the Chicago Region’s emissions inventory. These GHG protocols used in the 2010 Regional GHG Inventory are listed below, and were applied to each sector, as relevant and as discussed below for each emissions sector. 

The LGOP for Greenhouse Gas Assessments developed by ICLEI, CAR, TCR and CARB (California Air Resources Board 2010a): This protocol includes methods for estimating emissions resulting from government buildings and facilities, government fleet vehicles, wastewater treatment and potable water treatment facilities, landfill and composting facilities, and other operations. This protocol was developed primarily for use by California local governments; although it contains methodologies for estimating emissions pertinent to community emissions sources. Further, this protocol can be modified for use outside of California, although in some cases, data sources or other references may need to be modified accordingly to local conditions or constraints.

The USEPA Inventory of U.S. Greenhouse Gas Emissions and Sinks: 1990–2007 (U.S. Environmental Protection Agency 2009a): The national inventory documentation includes standard methodology and emission factors for nationwide GHG emissions inventorying. 

The IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories (Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change 2006a): This document is the international standard for inventories and provides much of the baseline methodology used in the national and statewide emission inventories. 

The GHG Protocol Corporate Standard developed by WRI and the WBCSD (World Resources Institute 2004): Although this is a protocol designed for use primarily by private corporations, it was one of the first documents to establish the principles and steps to developing a GHG inventory. This document has influenced the development of other types of GHG protocols, including those for municipal, government, and community-wide emissions.

Emissions are commonly divided into three categories or “scopes”, as follows (World Resources Institute 2004):
Scope 1: Direct GHG emissions, such as emissions from combustion of natural gas or in vehicles, where the emission occurs directly at the activity causing the emission.
Scope 2: Indirect GHG emissions, such as emissions associate with the consumption of electricity due to power plant emissions or methane emissions at a landfill that receives waste , where the emissions occur at a location separate from the activity causing the emission.

Scope 3: All other indirect emissions not covered in Scope 2 that are not owned or controlled by the reporting jurisdiction, such as the emissions resulting from the extraction and production of purchased materials and fuels.
The 2010 Regional GHG Inventory includes Scope 1 and 2 emissions (World Resources Institute 2004), including all direct and indirect emissions; Scope 3 emissions are not included.

Primary Methodology: International Emissions Analysis Protocol (ICLEI)
Methodology Details: The City also participated in a Regional Greenhouse Gas Emissions Inventory with other Southern Nevada jurisdictions, which analyzed regional energy consumption and total emissions for power, gas, transportation, and waste for the residential, commercial and industrial sectors from all community-related activities (e.g., residential and commercial buildings, motor vehicles, waste streams, industry). Scope 1 and Scope 2 emissions were input into the Clean Air Climate Protection (CACP) 2009 software tool following ICLEI protocol.  The first inventory was completed in early 2011 and was updated in early 2012.
The metodology is top - down, using data of primary energy source amount.

Primary Methodology: Other: City of Stockholm's standard. Developed in1996
Methodology Details:
Stockholm collect energy statistics and calculates it into CO2e.
Stockolm include CO2, CH4, N2O. In addition, we calculate the emissions from the fuel throughout the life cycle (LCA).

The city calculates the emissions from the production of heat, cold production, electricity use and energy to transport within the city limits.

The city collects the statistics from:
The energy for district heating, district cooling and gas distrubuerad in the city, from the local energy company.
Oil deliveries and electricity from the national government statistics office.
Energy for transport from the city's research department.

Primary Methodology: 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories
Methodology Details:
The methodology was developed by the Climate / COPPE / UFRJ, from the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas, with the adjustments already made in the Inventory of Anthropogenic Emissions and Removals of Greenhouse Gas Emissons not Controlled by Montreal Protocol - Initial Communication of Brazil (MCT, 2004), and upgraded to the standard division in scopes as in GHG Protocol.

The main methodological issue considered is the delimitation of the inventory scope, by restricting those sources whose emissions result only from socio-economic activities in the responsibility of the Municipality of Rio de Janeiro, considering that these are activities that may suffer interference municipal government. The inventory, so called Emissions Inventory Greenhouse Gas of Rio de Janeiro City and not, "in Rio de Janeiro City," does not incorporate the emissions occurring in the geographical boundaries of the municipality, but those occurring under their responsibility. 

By the end of 2011, the GHG emissions inventory from the city of Rio de Janeiro report was adapted to enable its presentation/comparison according to the emerging global protocol for community-scale greenhouse gas inventories, which Global Basic Standard for Community GHG Inventories disaggregates the emissions in three different scopes:
Scope 1 includes all direct emissions of GHG within the geographical boundaries of the city.
Scope 2 includes indirect GHG emissions associated with the consumption of purchased electricity. These emissions are caused by the share of electricity consumption in the city of Rio de Janeiro that is generated outside the city.
Scope 3 includes some indirect GHG emissions not accounted in Scopes 1 and 2.
It is worth to mention that the standard used to develop this inventory reflects global best practice, with input from academia, WRI, and World Bank, and is believed to be consistent with emerging international standards such as those being discussed by ICLEI-C40 (of which Rio de Janeiro is a member of both).

The reductions of GHG emissions presented at the point 4.4 of this questionnaire are related to the more conservative scenario established by the Inventory (Scenario B), considering the year of 2020 (limit of the period of reduction targets established by Law n. 5248/2011).

Primary Methodology: 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories
Methodology Details: Green house gas protocol worksheets are used

Primary Methodology: International Emissions Analysis Protocol (ICLEI)
Methodology Details: This inventory was conducted using processes developed by ICLEI for their Cities for Climate Protection Program.  ICLEI provided an Excel-based Master Data Workbook to aid with the data organization.  Data was then entered into ICLEI’s emissions-calculating software, Clean Air-Climate Protection (2009) version 3.0 (CACP).  CACP is the primary tool used by local governments in the United States to conduct greenhouse gas emissions inventories.  Prior to data entry into CACP, some coefficients must be manually entered.  This inventory used a list of published electricity emissions factors by EPA’s Emission and Generation Resource Integrated Database (eGRID) for region SERC Midwest for 2005, and the North American Electric Reliability Corporation (NERC) electricity factors for criteria air pollutants for 2005 for the region represented by map number 04.

EMEP (Cooperative programme for monitoring and evaluation of the long-range transmission of air pollutants in Europe)-CORINAIR METHODOLOGY harmonized with IPCC.

The municipal emissions inventory takes into account the six main GHG (carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide, hydrofluorocarbons, perflurocarbons and sulphur hexafluoride) and other major air pollutants considered in the methodology (heavy metals, particles, SO2, NOx, NMVOCs,CO,NH3, POPs) that could also have an indirect effect on climate change due to gaseous chemical reactions (ozone production).

Primary Methodology: The International Basic Standard for Community-Scale GHG Emission Inventories (ICLEI/C40/WB)
Methodology Details:
Currently, Toronto’s emissions calculations focus on our major emissions sources – energy (heating and cooling), transportation (mobile sources), and waste.

a. Energy Heating and Cooling:
Electricity and natural gas consumption for some City Departments (ABCCDs) are monitored through the Facilities Management Division. Emissions factors for electricity and natural gas are applied to consumption data in order to arrive at a GHG emissions total. The City of Toronto’s emissions factors for electricity and natural gas are updated annually and based on the National Inventory Reports (Environment Canada); however, the City of Toronto adds a 10% transmission loss to the NIR figure.

b. Transportation: 
Data are collected and standardized only for car and truck traffic through the City using four main sources: 
o truck traffic counts of approximately 200 intersections throughout the city from the City of Toronto’s Transportation Services Division
o accumulated traffic count data from years 1987 to 2004 from the City of Toronto’s Transportation Services Division
o the number of Ministry of Transportation registered vehicles in the City, and;
o a Canadian standard developed by a Canadian consultant

The above traffic data is then used to calculate “vehicle kilometers traveled” (VKT) and the EPA’s Mobil 6.2 software is used to calculate total emissions from mobile sources.

c. Waste: 
Tonnages of waste and approximate waste compositions are used in mass balance equations in the calculation of emissions from landfills.

Primary Methodology: Other: Propietary methodology
Methodology Details:
Even though the City used a propietary methodology, with the assistance of private consultants, the International Local Government GHG Emissions Analysis Protocol (ICLEI) was frequently consulted. 

Processing the received data.

The data was processed using the software EMS, which calculates GHG emissions, converted to carbon dioxide equivalent using information on energy consumption (fuel, natural gas, electricity) for activities, emission factor, calorific power and density of energy used.

For the community inventory, the methodology used in the Energy Sector was the one used for the Government operation inventory. That is, stating the KWh/year consumed by the 3 sub categories, and multiplying by the emission factor of the grid. As for gas consumption, m3 of gas consumed, calorific power of natural gas, density of the gas and its emissions factor (IPCC 2006 default) were considered in the equation. 

For the private transport sector and buses, GHG emissions were calculated using the EMS software, which required, for each sub categories within the sector, the amount of circulating cars by type of fuel consumed and the amount and type of fuel sold in the city. Fuel consumed by industries and government’s fleet was subtracted to the amount of fuel sold leaving amount of fuel consumed by vehicles.

For the other public transport sector, trains and subways, GHG emissions were calculated from electricity and diesel consumed when travelling within the City. Kilometers travelled and energy consumption data,  was obtained from the National Regulatory Commission of transport, and Metrovías (Subway grant company) 

For the Waste sector, the methodology used was one developed by the Intergovernmental Panel of Climate Change (IPCC), “Tool to determine methane emissions avoided from disposal of waste at a solid waste of disposal site”. In order to apply this methodology, it was necessary to obtain both the amount of Municipal Solid Waste (MSW) generated in the City of Buenos Aires in each of the years considered in the inventory, as well as their composition. 

For the Water treatment sector, the energy consumed is calculated multiplying the amount of water supplied (m3) and the energy consumed per m3 of treated and distributed water.

City Name: Government of Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
Primary Methodology: 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories
Methodology Details: The 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories contain the latest calculation methodologies adopted internationally to compile complete, national inventories of greenhouse gases.

Primary Methodology: 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories
Methodology Details: Warsaw prepared the inventory (more precisely, the calculation of carbon footprint)  in 2008, which covered the years 1990, 1995, 2000 and 2007. The methodology used was taken from the United Nations IPCC works. The area of calculation was: electricity and heat used, transport (public and individual), communal waste management, sewage treatment as well as carbon sequestration by soil and biomass. The emissions from electricity used were calculated by first collecting the information from the users and then multiplying it by an appropriate CO2 emissions indicator based on national energy mix in Poland. The same indicator was used for years 1990, 1995, 2000, while for the year 2007 the indicator was different. The emissions from heat were calculated using the data about production of heat from different types of fuel. Next, on the basis of CO2 emissions indicators for each kind of fuel the final calculation was done. The calculation for transport was divided in four categories: individual cars, pick-ups, lorries and public transport. For each of them different indicators of CO2 emissions were used, depending on the year of vehicle production as well as on the share in the modal split. With regard to waste management, the amount of waste and the way of dealing with it allowed to calculate the emissions of different GHG in CO2 equivalent. The amount and characteristics of communal sewage, as well as the way it was treated, allowed to calculate the emissions of different GHG in CO2 equivalent.

Primary Methodology: 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories
Methodology Details:
Identify GHG emissions from potential sector, such energy using, transportation, solid waste, waste water, and industrial.
Inventory GHG emissions and transportation as potential source.
Identify mitigaton action through define criteria and scooring

City Name: Free and Hanseatic City of Hamburg
Primary Methodology: 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories
Methodology Details:
The emissions figures in fields C1.4-C1.6 do solely state Hamburg’s CO2 emissions (sum of Scope 1 and Scope 2 emissions) – they do not include any CH4, N2O etc. emissions. This is due to the statistical principles used in Germany for the "Energiebilanzen der Bundesländer" (energy balances of the German federal states) and the "CO2-Bilanzen der Bundesländer" (CO2 balances of the German federal states), which are based on the energy consumption within the respective statistical area.
Nevertheless, these figures do reflect Hamburg’s CO2e emissions quite accurately, because CH4, N2O etc. emissions only cause about 4% of Hamburg’s overall CO2e emissions.

Primary Methodology: The International Basic Standard for Community-Scale GHG Emission Inventories (ICLEI/C40/WB)
Methodology Details: For community data, City specific data was used where available, such as utility provided records. If City specific data was not available, relevant values were extrapolated by population ratios from County or State data.

Primary Methodology: Other: Bilan Carbone (R)
Methodology Details:
We counted the direct and indirect GHG emissions that made possible the activity of the Paris territory as it was in 2009. e.g. for 1 liter of gasoline consumed in a parisian vehicle, the GHG emissions related to oil extraction, refining, and engine combustion are considered.

The methodology used is the Bilan Carbone (R) methodology, that gives national calculation ratios and rules to apply within the French territory. This method gives CO2e emissions aggregated for the 6 GHG gases of the Kyoto protocol.

Primary Methodology: Other: Proprietary methodology
Methodology Details:
The City of Seattle’s methodology is guided by the IPCC Guidelines for the National Greenhouse Gas Inventories and the GHG Protocol (2004), which was developed by both the World Business Council for Sustainable Development and the World Resources Institute. The inventory is based primarily on a geographic approach, and includes all emissions within a certain geographic boundary with a couple of exceptions. All emissions in the inventory are from within the Seattle city limits, with the exception of air travel and energy production. Emissions were calculated using an excel spreadsheet. 

Total emissions includes Scope 3 emissions.  The 143,604 Scope 2 emissions are offset by City Light .

The methodology used provides an inventory of greenhouse gases at the municipality level, divided into sectors. The sectors are similar to those used for the official Danish emission inventory (IPCC sectors), and include: collective power and heating, Individual heating, mobile sources, transportation and machinery, industrial processes, solvents, agriculture, land use, and waste depositing and wastewater.

Simplified generalizations of the equations used for emission calculations are used. These are based on the assumption that emissions of a given activity can be estimated using data descriptive for the size of the activity multiplied by an emission factor pr unit of activity. That is, the inventory is primarily based on scope-2 data on heat and power consumption and scope-1 data on road traffic. 

The method includes CO2-, CH4- and N2O-emission in the inventory. 

As for the national inventories the calculation is built into several levels (Tiers) with increased requirements for municipalities regarding data quality. Each municipality may use different tiers for different sectors depending on the data availability.

Tier 1 is mainly based on the Danish national greenhouse gas inventory data using appropriate distribution keys, in most cases the municipality's share of total population, for a given activity into municipality level. 

Tier 2 is more detailed and includes emission factors used in the Danish national greenhouse gas inventories, while municipalities use their own activity data. 

At Tier 3, which is the most detailed level; municipalities use municipality specific emission factors and activity data.

Primary Methodology: Other: IPCC Guidelines for National Inventories of Greenhouse Gases 1986
Methodology Details: We used the IPCC Guidelines for National Inventories of Greenhouse Gases (1986)
Methodology included a combination of Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) reported emission factors and EPA recommended emission modeling tools.

Primary Methodology: International Emissions Analysis Protocol (ICLEI)
Methodology Details: See uploaded methodology document.

Primary Methodology: International Emissions Analysis Protocol (ICLEI)
Methodology Details:
Residential/Commercial/Industrial/Direct Access Electricity: The majority of electricity used by these sectors is purchased from PG&E. Exceptions to this are power for municipal operations provided by the San Francisco Public Utility Commission and  Direct Access power customers. A San Francisco specific electricity factor is then applied to the usage figures to determine CO2 emissions.

Residential/Commercial/Industrial Natural Gas: The residential, commercial, industrial, and municipal sectors of San Francisco purchase their natural gas from PG&E. The California Climate Action Registry stationary natural emission factors are applied to the activity data to determine tons of GHGs. CO2, N2O, and CH4 registry factors are combined into a single CO2e factor. Emission factors for natural gas are based on combustion only and do not include upstream methane leakage from extraction and distribution of natural gas.

Municipal Electricity (including MUNI fleet electricity): Electricity usage data for municipal operations is obtained from the SFPUC. The Community EF is applied.

Municipal natural gas usage: Natural gas is delivered by PG&E.

Intra-regional & SF Road Vehicles:The SF County Transportation Agency provides modeled VMT data from its SFCHAMP model that includes all travel within San Francisco and assigns half of the VMT associated with trips into or outside of SF. The other half is attributed to the source or destination city. Pass-thru VMT are excluded from the total. 

Guidance from the Metropolitan Transportation Commission. CO2e emissions are provided by the Bay Air Area Quality Management District using the Air Resource Board’s EMFAC model database.  

Rail – Caltrain Diesel Fuel: Estimates on total system fuel usage are obtained as well as passenger data, specifically total ridership and number of de-boardings in San Francisco. The % of trips de-boarding in San Francisco is share of trips attributable to San Francisco. This percentage is then applied to the total fuel usage, and that amount of fuel is multiplied by the California Climate Action Registry CO2 factor for diesel from mobile sources to determine emissions.
 
Rail – BART Electricity: Market area data and total system power consumption was obtained; Transbay and Westbay ridership was considered attributable to San Francisco and was divided by total ridership to determine a market share % for San Francisco. This market share % is multiplied by total system power usage to determine the San Francisco share of power usage. 
  
Ferry – Diesel Fuel:Ferry data is an estimation of emissions from all Bay Area leisure and commuter ferries.

Community Wide Electricity Emissions Factor: Within the City and County of San Francisco there are three distinct sources of electricity. The first and largest is PG&E which currently serves all residential and the majority of commercial buildings. The second are a small classification of commercial customers who purchase their power directly from power providers; these are known as Direct Access Customers. The third set of customers is those that purchase from the municipal San Francisco Public Utilities Commission. Each of these electric providers has a different carbon factor which is applied to kWh consumer by their respective customers. For emissions estimates of the different resources that constitute the California Net System Power Mix, including coal, natural gas, hydro, nuclear, and renewable, staff used figures recently published by the California Public Utilities Commission. In addition, in order to take responsibility for emissions generated by in city power plants San Francisco also included the emissions from PG&E contracted electric power plants located within the City and County of San Francisco as part of the emissions profile of PG&E customers.

1) Local Generation: GHG emissions produced by major facilities located within San Francisco. 
2) Owned Generation: The total electricity used by the City and County of San Francisco for municipal government operations, primarily carbon free power from SFPUC’s Hetch Hetchy hydro electric system.
3) Imported Power: This includes electricity consumed by Direct Access customers. Since very little information is publicly available on the resources procured by ESPs for non-BART DA customers, SFE staff estimated an emissions factor for the rest of DA electricity for the California Energy Commission (CEC) annual “California Net System Power Mix” as a proxy for an average DA resource portfolio.   

For emissions estimates of the different resources that constitute the California Net System Power Mix, including coal, natural gas, hydro, nuclear, and renewable, staff used figures recently published by the California Public Utilities Commission.

Primary Methodology: The International Basic Standard for Community-Scale GHG Emission Inventories (ICLEI/C40/WB)
Methodology Details: District government hired ICLEI to gather and analyse data related to completing our community GHG inventory, using data for the year 2006.

Primary Methodology: International Emissions Analysis Protocol (ICLEI)
Methodology Details: Calculations are made with national community-scale ghg inventory model (Kasvener), which is based on IPCC parameters, and further adjusted for Helsinki Metropolitan Area with weather correction, benefit allocation method for CHP and national emission factor for electricity.

Primary Methodology: The International Basic Standard for Community-Scale GHG Emission Inventories (ICLEI/C40/WB)
Methodology Details: We used de GHG Protocol and IPCC Guidelines

Primary Methodology: Other: UK National Atmospheric Emissions Inventory
Methodology Details:
The data presented here represent a spatial disaggregation of the CO2 from the UK Greenhouse Gas Inventory (GHGI), part of the National Atmospheric Emissions Inventory (NAEI), on an end user basis. The CO2 emissions are estimated, by sector, for each local authority in the UK.

The UK official Greenhouse Gas inventory (GHGI) is compiled annually by AEA on behalf of the Department for Energy and Climate Change (DECC) as part of the NAEI programme. The GHGI is compiled and reported using international best practice guidance and draws on a variety of National Statistics and sector specific data sources. The UK GHGI is reported each year to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) and the European Monitoring Mechanism (EUMM) and is used to assess compliance with the targets set nationally and internationally such as in the Kyoto Protocol. A consistent method and common base of activity data is used across the NAEI programme. This provides internally consistent inventories and emissions projections of greenhouse gases and air quality pollutants.
